Tercen Book Faris Naji, Alexandre Maurel Preface This is a book about Tercen. Why read this book? It is the centralized knowledge of Tercen in book form. It is detailed and is aimed for a deeper understanding of Tercen. If you require to have a quick intro to Tercen then we suggest you read the starters guide. Structure of the book There is an introduction chapter1 Acknowledgement I would like to thank all the users for their feedback about Tercen. It has helped us improve Tercen. Feedback If you wish to give feedback then please do not hesitate to create an entry in the issue tracker.

About the authors Faris Naji has over ten years experience in trying to remove data barriers in science. Lives in Amsterdam and thinks bikes are the solution to urban living (at least in Europe). Alexandre Maurel has over ten years experience in building high data performance tools. Lives in the south of France and is always on the lookout for a good restaurant.

Chapter 1 Introduction 1.1 Motivation Tercen promotes collaboration for data analysis. Not everyone can code or even wants to, but everyone should benefit from the explosion of data and code currently taking place. Tercen allows non programmers (e.g. biologists) to explore their data and allows programmers (e.g. bioinformaticians) to upload their code (or web-apps) for the biologist to use. By offering this services we believe biologist get empowered and can claim back control of their data. The bioinformatician gets liberated from the operational details and day to day analysis demands from the biologist. This is summed up with the phrase: Tercen empowers the biologist and liberates the bioinformatician.

Chapter 2 Tercen Features 2.1 Generate any visual 2.2 Visual computation 2.3 Workflow analysis and customization 2.4 Integrate external knowledge 2.5 Sharing analysis 2.6 Sharing data 2.7 Programmatic access 2.8 Add plug-in apps 2.9 Project centric analysis 2.10 Data provenance 2.11 Cloud hosted or on-site 2.12 Zero install

Chapter 2 Tercen Features Here is an overview of Tercen features. 2.1 Generate any visual The researcher configures any graphical view (e.g. heatmaps, plots, time series, kinetic time series and parallel co-ordinates, pairwise scatter plots) without the aid of a bioinformatician. 2.2 Visual computation The researcher defines a computation (e.g. mean, ANOVA, Mixed-Model, count) visually and in so doing defines a new computation without the aid of bioinformatician. Process any large numeric data: Researcher can upload and process any type of large numerical data (e.g. genomic, flow cytometry, proteomic) without the aid of a bioinformatician. 2.3 Workflow analysis and customization The researcher visually customizes a workflow without the aid of a bioinformatician. A workflow is a pipeline data analysis composed of a sequence of computation and annotation steps. There are standard workflows for each of molecular readouts (e.g. RNAseq, flowCyto, mass-spectroscopy spectra). 2.4 Integrate external knowledge The researcher integrates extra data from external data or knowledge sources (e.g. biological, clinical, and chemical) without the aid of a bioinformatician, (e.g. Uniprot, Protein atlas, Reactome). 2.5 Sharing analysis The researcher shares the workflow and data via an URL and both researcher and bioinformatician can collaborate on the same workflow and data at the same time. 2.6 Sharing data The researcher shares the measurement and computed data via URL to other parties. Raw measurement data or newly analysed data is shareable to any users with internet. Results reporting: The researcher generates an extensive report on the complete workflow for collaborators, presentations or publication. The report contains not only the conclusions but an automatically generated formal description of the complete process (e.g. normalization, statistics testing, clustering, functional annotation). This is essential for reproducible science. The aid of the bioinformatician is not needed. 2.7 Programmatic access Bioinformaticians accesses and manipulates the analysis and components through their favorite programming environment (e.g. R, RShiny, Python, Matlab, Javascript). 2.8 Add plug-in apps The researcher easily adds powerful computation or visualization plug-ins without the aid of a bioinformatician. These plugins are developed by the bioinformatician and transmitted via the TercenCloud platform. Plug-ins are computation or visualization modules (e.g. vsn normalization, ANOVA, PCA, MDS, Mixed Models, clustering). 2.9 Project centric analysis The researcher centralizes all the data, workflow and visuals in one project and sets access control without the aid of an IT administration. 2.10 Data provenance The researcher traces any computed value back to the initial measurement without the aid of a bioinformatician. 2.11 Cloud hosted or on-site The researcher shares the complete process via a secure internet connection to secure cloud service, all computation resources (CPU, RAM and hard disk) are dynamically allocated to the researcher without the aid of an IT administration. Tercen is also availabe for onsite deployment. 2.12 Zero install Researcher immediately starts performing analysis using a browser on any device without the aid of an IT administration

Chapter 5 Operators 5.1 App library 5.2 Structure of an operator 5.3 Tercen R package

Chapter 5 Operators Tercen operators perform the computation on the projection views. There are many existing operators but it is easy to create your own operator. Using the data step, a user creates a projection and selects an operator. A data projection is composed of a data, y-axis, x-axis, rowseq, colseq, color and label. All these projection parameter are presented by data structures to the operator. 5.1 App library All Tercen are on tercen github. 5.2 Structure of an operator A Tercen operator is composed of three main activities: Get data Operate on data Return results All the projection parameters are available as data frames: For the data itself Tercen supplies three variables. .ri row sequence of data, represented by an integer .ci col sequence of data, represented by an integer .id id sequence of data (will be deprecated), represented by an integer 5.3 Tercen R package There is currently an R package in the tercen repository to help in creating operators called teRcen

Chapter 6 Roadmap Tercen is complex software and requires to built up in stages with constant feedback. The alpha version allows for testing the value proposition and the feature list. The Beta and Final are about upscaling. Alpha Scheduled for begin 2016 Beta Scheduled for after summer 2017 Final Scheduled for mid 2018

Chapter 7 Known issues The alpha version of Tercen has the following known issues and limitations: By default users are not allowed to create operators unless explicitly given permission by a Tercen administrator Cannot perform an operator on multi pairwise projections If your local computer’s date and clock time is not the same as the Tercen server then you may get delays and errors Cannot run python scripts These issues are solved in the beta version scheduled to go live after summer.

Chapter 8 Getting started Here are some ideas: Try to upload different data sets and play with making different projection visuals Try to code for different operators using the rtercen R package, Note when using RStudio it will autocomplete when you type the methods on the tercen client and tercen query object. Give feedback on this starters’s guide by creating an issue Give feedback on Tercen by sending an email to info@tercen.com Contact us for a one-2-one session

Chapter 9 Glossary Measurement: A numerical variable Observation: An observation is the factor name given to a value (measurement), at a particular period, of a particular variable. Variable: A variable is a characteristic of a unit being observed that may assume more than one of a set of values to which a numerical measure or a category from a classification can be assigned (e.g. income, age, weight, etc., and “occupation”, “industry”, “disease”, etc Cross-tab: Projection: Long format: Wide format:
